content.definition: The saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ) is the anatomic termination point of the small saphenous vein (SSV) into the popliteal vein, typically located in the popliteal fossa. Understanding SPJ anatomy and its variations is essential for treating small saphenous vein insufficiency.

location: Variable height: typically 3-7 cm above knee crease
termination_patterns: Great saphenous vein via Giacomini vein (10-15%)

giacomini_vein.definition: Intersaphenous vein connecting SSV to GSV
giacomini_vein.course: Posterior-medial thigh from SPJ to GSV
clinical_significance: Alternative drainage when SPJ is absent
Route for reflux propagation between systems
Must be identified during SSV treatment

termination_height: Low: at or below popliteal crease
High: >7 cm above, into distal femoral vein
anatomic_variations.absence: True SPJ absent in 20-30% of limbs

preoperative_assessment.marking: Mark SPJ location on skin preoperatively in standing position

nerve_proximity: Sural nerve runs adjacent to SSV
Tibial nerve and popliteal vessels deep
Risk of nerve injury during SPJ surgery

learning_objectives: Describe SPJ anatomic location and variations
Identify Giacomini vein and its significance
clinical_pearls: True SPJ into popliteal vein exists in only 70-80% of limbs
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV - alternative drainage pathway
ALWAYS ultrasound map SPJ before treatment - highly variable
Sural nerve injury is major complication risk of SSV surgery
Height of SPJ varies significantly - cannot assume location
